Archaeologists Unearth a Reusable School Slate Still Covered in the Scribbles of Victorian Children
The slate was found alongside other evidence of young students’ schoolwork and play at the site of a new development in London
Archaeologists have discovered a trove of rare artifacts used by children at the site of a new development in London.
While preparing for construction, researchers unearthed several marbles, a pencil and a fragment of a reusable slate tablet with letters scratched into the surface.
“We don’t often find archaeological objects we can directly link to children, but here we were delighted to find evidence for both schoolwork and play,” according to a January 12 update from the Museum of London Archaeology (MOLA), which is leading the dig.
The marbles—some of which are still covered in colorful decorations—are what’s known as “ceramic alleys,” or small, smooth spheres designed to look like they were made from alabaster. They were discovered in a covered, brick-lined drain, which suggests they may have been lost during “a breaktime game,” per MOLA.
The tablet, meanwhile, was probably a useful tool for taking notes. “Children would have used chalk or slate pencils to copy down from the blackboard or practice their handwriting and rubbed them clean for the next lesson,” according to MOLA.
Archaeologists don’t know exactly how old the children’s artifacts are, but they hope to find out. They’re also trying to make out the scribbles on the tablet, per Fox News Digital’s Andrea Margolis.
“We’re currently exploring this as part of our post-excavation work on the site, so we hope to be able to share more soon,” Alex Blanks, a MOLA senior archaeologist, tells the outlet.
The dig site, located in east London, will soon be home to SEGRO Park Wapping, a new industrial and logistics hub. However, hundreds of years ago, it was home to a free school for impoverished boys, as well as residences for poor elderly people.
The researchers say these structures were established in 1536 by Nicholas Gibson, an elected sheriff of London, and later supported by his widow, Avice Knyvet, who asked the Worshipful Company of Coopers to look after them.
The group made and repaired wooden casks and barrels in London starting in the 1400s, but it also supported charities and education initiatives. Many residents of the community had direct links to the profession—such as a father, husband or son who worked as a cooper.
According to a 1598 survey of London, the structures were “for the instruction of 60 poor men’s children, a schoolmaster and usher with fifty pounds ... also ... alms houses for 14 poor aged persons, each of them to receive quarterly six shillings and eight pence the piece for ever,” per MOLA. The homes’ first inhabitants were primarily older, widowed women, but by 1720, men were also living at the site, records show. Each resident had a room, a cellar and a small garden.
In addition to the children’s items, archaeologists also unearthed the remains of a chapel, row houses and other buildings, as well as brick-lined cesspits and wells filled with items. The dig revealed a “little microcosm of a whole community,” Blanks tells BBC News’ Tim Stokes.
The excavation turned up artifacts ranging from the Roman occupation of London (from the first to the fifth centuries) to the Victorian period (from 1837 to 1901), including pieces of glassware, pottery and clay pipes.
Did you know? Château Margaux
The prestigious French vineyard Château Margaux was a favorite of famous figures like Thomas Jefferson, America’s third president, and Robert Walpole, Britain’s first prime minister.
Archaeologists also recovered the seal from a bottle of wine produced by a high-end French winery called Château Margaux. That was a bit of a surprise, because the area—which was once known as Sailor Town—was long considered “overcrowded and dangerous,” Blanks says in a statement.
“But finds like this are revealing a more complex social history than often biased contemporary sources would have you believe,” he adds. “In reality, it was a very diverse area—just like the East End is today. Archaeological evidence ... suggests people from a wide range of social standings may have been living in the area and getting to enjoy some of the same luxuries as the richest in society.”

An Asian Elephant Was Born at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo for the First Time in Almost 25 Years. Now, You Can Help Pick Her Name
The calf was born to 12-year-old Nhi Linh, a first-time mother, and 44-year-old Spike. The pair bred as part of a program working to conserve the endangered species
In the wee hours of February 2, the world welcomed a new Asian elephant. She is the first calf of this species born at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute (NZCBI) since late 2001.
Soon after the baby’s birth at 1:15 A.M. Eastern Standard Time, staff performed a neonatal exam and deemed her “healthy, alert and bright-eyed,” according to a statement. At the time, she weighed 308 pounds and measured 38.5 inches tall.
Assisting with the birth is “really hard to describe, because it’s something I’ve wanted to do for years,” Robbie Clark, elephant manager and acting curator of Elephant Trails at NZCBI, tells Smithsonian magazine. “I’m honestly still absorbing what happened. I haven’t slept since she was born.”
This bundle of joy was born to first-time mother Nhi Linh, who is 12 years old, after a 21-month-long pregnancy. She bred with 44-year-old Spike in April 2024. The calf will not be viewable by Zoo visitors for up to a month while she bonds with her mom, the rest of the herd and animal care staff.
The baby doesn’t have a name yet, and NZCBI wants the public to help choose it. From today through February 13 at 12 P.M. Eastern Standard Time, fans who donate at least $5 to Asian elephant care and conservation through the Zoo’s website can choose from four options of Vietnamese origin, and $1 represents one vote:
Linh Mai [LIN-my]: Linh means “spirit” or “soul”; Mai refers to the apricot blossom, a flower associated with Tết (Lunar New Year), which begins February 17.
Thảo Nhi [TOW-nee]: Thảo means “gentle” or “kind” and is associated with nature; Nhi means “small,” “little one” or “beloved.”
Tú Anh [TOO-ahng]: Tú means “talented” or “gifted”; Anh means “bright” and “intelligent.”
Tuyết [TWET]: traditionally means “snow,” referencing the calf’s winter birth.
NZCBI will announce the calf’s name on its website in late February.
Parents Nhi Linh and Spike bred as part of a Species Survival Plan program, managed by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums, that aims to create a stable, genetically diverse population of Asian elephants. Fewer than 50,000 of these animals are estimated to remain in their homeland of South and Southeast Asia. “Asian elephants are very endangered. Actually, they’re ten times more endangered than African Elephants,” Peter Leimgruber, NZCBI’s director of conservation and science, tells Smithsonian magazine.
The species’ population continues to dwindle largely because of human-induced habitat loss from activities such as agriculture, mining and urbanization. But insights gained at the Zoo can help conservationists working with wild Asian elephants.
“Many of the things we learn here—technologies, the science—we can directly transfer to these places [where the animals live],” Leimgruber says. For example, staff could show people how to monitor the elephants’ reproductive cycles via hormones and determine which individuals should be bred to maintain genetic diversity, he notes.
Genetics, health and temperament helped experts determine that Spike and Nhi Linh should breed. Nhi Linh is described as having a “feisty and rambunctious” personality, per the statement. She arrived in the fall of 2022, along with her mother, 22-year-old Trong Nhi, as a gift from the Rotterdam Zoo in the Netherlands. Meanwhile, Spike seems to have a “relaxed and easygoing” personality, according to keepers, and came to NZCBI in the spring of 2018 on loan from Zoo Miami.
Fun fact: The last Asian elephant born at NZCBI
Male elephant Kandula was born at the Zoo on November 25, 2001. He left NZCBI when he was almost 14 years old and now lives at the Oklahoma City Zoo. His mother, Shanthi, stayed in Washington, D.C., and died at the estimated age of 45 in 2020.
Zoo staff have been carefully monitoring Nhi Linh over the past few months. In late January, blood draws revealed that her levels of the hormone progesterone had plummeted—a signal that she would soon give birth. On January 25, the care team began an around-the-clock watch to keep an eye out for behavioral signs of labor, such as tail flapping and abdominal muscle contractions.
A big indicator is something called the bulge. “That’s when the calf has moved with contractions to a point where you can see externally it’s pushing and getting ready to move,” Clark says. That happened soon after 12:30 A.M. Eastern Standard Time on February 2, he adds, “and within a half hour, her water had broken and the calf was on the ground.”
The calf has not yet met her mother. The two can smell and hear one another, but a barrier sits between them. Staff are watching behavioral cues to assess when Nhi Linh might be ready to meet her baby. An encouraging sign that they’re currently seeing is Nhi Linh being the only elephant to respond to the calf’s calls, Clark says.
“Once we can secure that bond—and typically, the magic point is nursing—then we’ll give them a little time to learn how to orientate around each other,” he says.

articles.content:
‘Golden’ From ‘Kpop Demon Hunters’ Just Won K-Pop’s Very First Grammy
The hit song, a demon-slaying self-empowerment anthem, was recognized as the Best Song Written for Visual Media
“It’s so incredible to have the song ‘Golden’ being sung all over the world—singing the Korean lyrics word by word, it means so much,” Kim Eun-jae, known to fans as Ejae, said on February 1 after accepting the Grammy Award for Best Song Written for Visual Media. The victory marked the first time a K-pop song has taken home a Grammy.
Ejae, Audrey Nuna and Rei Ami provided the singing voices for the three members of the fictional K-pop girl group Huntr/x in Maggie Kang and Chris Appelhans’s 2025 animated movie Kpop Demon Hunters, which smashed records to become the most-watched movie in Netflix history.
As Elle Hunt writes for the Guardian, the movie centers around the members of the group Huntr/x, who are “responsible for protecting humanity from supernatural threats with their combat skills and empowering pop.” Their main rivals are the Saja Boys, a competing boy band whose members moonlight as evil demons.
The songs that Huntr/x uses in battle have proven effective in more than just demon fighting: They have also skyrocketed to global renown. Kpop Demon Hunters was the first-ever soundtrack to have four songs in the top ten of the Billboard Hot 100 at the same time. It also reached top-ten status in 93 countries. Kayti Burt of Time magazine attributes the soundtrack’s success to the fact that it’s more meaningful to the plot than a typical background score. “It is integral to the story,” writes Time. “All of the film’s music holds the power to influence its in-world listeners.”
However, none of the songs made a bigger impression than the Grammy-winning “Golden,” which ruled the top slot on Billboard’s Global 100 for eight weeks and became Spotify’s seventh most-streamed song for 2025.
The Grammy went to songwriters Ejae, Park Hong Jun, Joong Gyu Kwak, Yu Han Lee, Hee Dong Nam, Jeong Hoon Seo and Mark Sonnenblick. “Golden” comes at a crucial moment in Kpop Demon Hunters, when Huntr/x is trying to seal a barrier between the real and supernatural worlds. With that scene of the film already planned, Ejae was tasked with writing a song that would express the emotions of the characters in that moment, Ejae told Variety’s Jazz Tangcay last year.
Ejae added that the melody came to her first, while she was on the way to a dentist appointment. The idea for the titular “gonna be golden” lyrics came to her later, and she built out a song that speaks to self-empowerment using both English and Korean lyrics.
“It was important for our co-director, Maggie Kang, to have Korean in the lyrics,” Ejae told Variety. “And I just love that it’s not just the verses; it was in the actual song too.”
After a record-breaking year for the Kpop Demon Hunters film, many critics were unsurprised by the success of “Golden” at the Grammys. At the same time, others point out that award recognition for the K-pop genre is overdue.
Quick fact: What is K-pop?
The genre—which draws on inspiration from pop, rock, hip-hop and dance music—began in South Korea in the 1990s and spread across the globe.
“For years, the Recording Academy has snubbed K-pop acts that have set record-breaking standards, such as BTS, Seventeen and Stray Kids,” Areum Jeong, a Korean studies scholar at Arizona State University, told the Associated Press’ Maria Sherman a few weeks before the Grammys. “I think one of the main reasons is that the Western world is still so resistant to non-English lyrics.”
Meanwhile, Mathieu Berbiguier, a Korean studies scholar at Carnegie Mellon University, told the AP that “Golden,” along with other songs that feature both English and Korean lyrics, might help bring K-pop into the pop music mainstream.
With the Grammy win for “Golden” secured, the artists of Kpop Demon Hunters still have other award shows to anticipate. The film is in the running for Best Animated Feature Film at the 98th Academy Awards this March, where “Golden” was also nominated for Best Original Song. That nomination made it the first-ever Oscar nomination in the K-pop genre.
After the Oscar nominations were announced, Ejae reflected to Billboard’s Hannah Dailey that, as a child, she was made fun of for liking K-pop music.
“It’s incredible,” she added. “To see [K-pop] just growing more and more and being part of a film that’s really showcasing it in the most authentic way.”

Some Polar Bears Have Been Getting Chunkier—Despite Losing Their Main Hunting Grounds to Climate Change
The fuzzy white predators of Svalbard, Norway, have been getting fatter over the past two decades, possibly by changing their diets and hunting strategies, a new study suggests
Arctic temperatures are rising nearly four times faster than those in the rest of the world, resulting in the loss of sea ice there. Yet, one group of polar bears—which rely on sea ice to hunt their main prey, seals—has recently fattened up, despite the habitat decline.
Measurements of 770 adult polar bears of the Barents Sea subpopulation, which live around Norway’s Svalbard archipelago, suggest that the animals have plumped up from 2000 to 2019, according to a paper published January 29 in Scientific Reports. Researchers behind the new work suggest that the predators might be shifting their diets and hunting tactics in response to climate change, unveiling a complex relationship between the ecosystem and the creatures’ energy intake and expenditure.
“When I started, if you asked me, ‘What do you think will happen?’ I would assume they would be struggling and they would get leaner, skinnier and maybe you would see effects on reproduction and survival,” study co-author Jon Aars, a polar bear ecologist at the Norwegian Polar Institute, tells the New York Times’ Eric Niiler. “That was wrong.”
Still, the encouraging signs might be short-lived, he notes.
Fun fact: Additional hopeful polar bear news
Late last year, researchers realized that a polar bear mom named X33991 in the western Hudson Bay subpopulation adopted a cub. This is only the 13th known instance of adoption within the well-studied group. You can track the family, which also includes a cub that the mom birthed, thanks to X33991’s GPS collar.
The data came from nearly 1200 bear captures that took place each spring from 1995 to 2019. From a helicopter, Aars and his colleagues shot tranquilizer darts at the animals, and then they landed to take various measurements, including body length and the circumference around the chest. They used a body condition index (BCI) to estimate each bear’s fat reserves based on its size and weight.
Analyses revealed that the marine mammals did slim down during the first few years of the study. But their weight started to rise after 2000, despite a rapid loss in sea ice that has diminished their main hunting grounds, the team found.
Why have the bears been thriving, against all odds? Based on recent observations, the researchers suggest that the animals may have turned to alternative food sources, such as reindeer and walrus carcasses, whose populations have increased due to hunting bans. Additionally, the predators might have changed seal-hunting tactics. During years with less sea ice, ringed seals—the Svalbard bears’ main springtime snack—seem to congregate in higher densities, making it easier to spot and catch the prey.
The new research demonstrates how polar bears are “part of a ‘complex relationship’ that includes habitat, multiple prey species, their ability as predators and their ability to store energy,” Lori Quakenbush, a biologist at the Alaska Department of Fish and Game’s Arctic Marine Mammal Program who wasn’t involved in the study, says to Scientific American’s Jackie Flynn Mogensen.
Still, the sea ice changes may have unequal impacts on individual bears within the group. While some of them stick around the Svalbard area and eat more land-based food, others migrate in the spring to munch on more marine-based meals, often swimming a few hundred miles to a Russian archipelago, the study authors write in the paper. With the retreat of sea ice, the latter group will have to travel even farther to reach hunting grounds, a trip that the researchers describe as “energetically demanding.”
And the effects of climate change and other habitat factors are different for each of the 20 recognized subpopulations of polar bears—consisting of roughly 26,000 individuals—that live around the Arctic. Within the past two decades, two groups have likely been growing their numbers, five groups seem stable and three groups have been losing bears, according to the conservation organization Polar Bears International. The other subpopulations lack enough data to make estimates.
“As you lose ice, eventually you lose bears,” says John Whiteman, chief scientist for the group and a biologist at Old Dominion University who wasn’t involved in the study, to the Times. “But the question is, in that short term, what are the regional circumstances, and will they allow bears to persist for a while in the face of ice loss?”

Fervent Fans of ‘Moby-Dick’ Flock to This Massachusetts City to Read the Book Cover to Cover
Once the whaling capital of the world, New Bedford remembers Herman Melville’s literary masterpiece with an annual reading marathon
On a recent cold winter’s afternoon, the faithful gathered at the high altar of literary devotion to hear the gospel preached by a pious soul. Congregants filled the seats of the tabernacle and ringed the loft like sailors at the taffrail of a ship leaving harbor on a long voyage. Many held their “bible” in prayerful hands to follow the impassioned preacher as he intoned the famous first line of that potent prose:
“Call me Ishmael.”
Thus began Massachusetts Poet Laureate Regie Gibson as he read the first chapter from what is regarded by many to be America’s greatest novel, Moby-Dick; or, the Whale by Herman Melville. Erupting in applause and shouts of joy, the overflow audience at the New Bedford Whaling Museum then settled in for a 25-hour-long reading by more than 300 people of the masterpiece, which tells the tale of a 19th-century whaling expedition wrought with obsession, tragedy, derangement and revenge.
For 30 years, the Moby-Dick Marathon has been an annual tradition in New Bedford. Once the whaling capital of the world, the Massachusetts port is where Melville departed on a voyage to the South Seas in 1841. This year, more than 3,100 devotees from around the country and across the seas attended the service, which began on January 3 (the 185th anniversary of Melville’s whaling trip), and nearly 250 remained overnight.
“It’s one of our oldest, greatest American novels,” Gibson says. “Connecting to the history and imagery that Melville gives us is astonishing. As a poet, reading it out loud you really see what poetic techniques are being used. There’s repetition; there is alliteration; there are subtle hints of rhyme; there is all of this beautiful stuff that he is doing to make it … a cavalcade of sound that brings you in like the sea does.”
The story of Moby-Dick
For the uninitiated, this tale of self-destruction is told through the perspective of Ishmael, who seeks to escape the “damp, drizzly November in my soul” by taking an ocean voyage. Along the way, he befriends harpooneer Queequeg, a Polynesian native who wants to experience the curious culture of American and European sailors. They sign on to the whale ship Pequod, captained by the fanatical Ahab, who lost his leg to a mighty white whale known as Moby-Dick. They set forth on their doomed voyage from New Bedford and sail to the Pacific Ocean, where an obsessed Ahab leads the hunt, only to lose his life, ship and most of his crew to the leviathan.
The allegorical nature of the story makes it even more profound. When Melville published Moby-Dick in 1851, the United States was on a cataclysmic course toward Civil War. The writer embellished his book with imagery evoking the coming conflict and the blind attitudes of a society bent on an all-consuming conflagration.
“It was an experimental novel,” says Nathaniel Philbrick, author of Why Read Moby-Dick? and other award-winning books on history, including In the Heart of the Sea, about the 1819 ship sunk by a whale that Melville built his story around. “It’s one of those timeless works of literature that is written at such a high level. It’s about a society on the verge of a catastrophe. Somehow, Melville works that into a story of a whaling voyage.”
Quick fact: "The city that lit the world"
- New Bedford, Massachusetts, was once the wealthiest city per capita in North America. Its wealth came from exporting whale oil, used in lamps and candles in the days before electricity, in the 19th century.
Born in 1819, Melville came from a wealthy background, though his father squandered that fortune. To survive, he worked a series of jobs, as a schoolteacher, shopkeeper and merchant mariner. He then tried his hand at whaling.
Melville took up writing after his experiences on the South Seas, which were recounted in the romanticized adventure-travel book Typee (1849), along with several novels and books of poetry. Sadly, Moby-Dick did not achieve the initial acclaim Melville hoped for, and his fame began to fade.
Melville died in 1891 believing his sacred tome had fallen on deaf ears. Amazingly, Moby-Dick sold fewer than 3,200 copies in his lifetime. Critics found the story “absurd,” and readers weren’t interested in a novel style that diverged so sharply from the simple adventure books they were used to reading. Scholars rediscovered his writings during a 1919 centennial celebration marking his birth. Moby-Dick gained popularity when Nobel laureate and author William Faulkner stated, “I wish I had written that.” He equated it to a Greek tragedy and viewed it as the pinnacle of American writing.
Philbrick echoed those sentiments when he wrote in 2011: “For me, Moby-Dick is more than the greatest American novel ever written; it is a metaphysical survival manual—the best guidebook there is for a literate man or woman facing an impenetrable unknown: the future of civilization in this storm-tossed 21st century.”
Whaling history runs deep in New Bedford
Masterwork aside, Melville is revered in New Bedford for his deferential descriptions of the city. When Moby-Dick resurfaced as a classic in the 20th century, it helped the community reclaim its early grandeur. For a time, New Bedford was the wealthiest community in the country because of the vast fortunes made from the whaling industry. At its peak in the mid-19th century, the port was known as “the city that lit the world,” because much of the oil from harvested whales was used in lamps. In 1857, 329 whaling ships valued at $12 million in today’s money called New Bedford home.
Melville’s ode to New Bedford in the novel remains a source of community pride:
The town itself is perhaps the dearest place to live in, in all New England. … Nowhere in all America will you find more patrician-like houses, parks and gardens more opulent, than in New Bedford. … All these brave houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans. One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up hither from the bottom of the sea.
Today, the city’s waterfront is filled with links to its whaling past and Melville’s novel, retaining much of its former glory in the form of cobblestone streets, elegant mansions and buildings, statues and memorials, and more. A brewery is even named after the great whale, and countless stores and cafés honor the literary masterpiece. But as pervasive as the whale is about town, what keeps the seaport vibrant today is the more humble sea scallop. New Bedford is now the hub for the world’s largest sea scallop fishery, and host to an annual scallop festival with a shucking contest and other events.
The shining temple of the city is the New Bedford Whaling Museum, where the Moby-Dick Marathon begins in an exhibit hall featuring the Lagoda, a large model of a whaling ship that sailed from New Bedford more than 150 years ago. While a series of readers lyrically delivers the humor and honesty of friendship on a shipboard journey, as well as the ferocity of a duel to the death on the high seas, listeners are enchanted by the presence of the half-scale replica of the three-masted bark that braved a trip around Cape Horn and plied the seas in search of bounty.
Opened in 1915 on historic Johnny Cake Hill, the museum houses more than 750,000 whaling-industry artifacts, including 3,000 pieces of scrimshaw (whale bones and teeth hand-etched by whalers) and 2,500 logbooks from whaling ships. Both collections are the largest of their kind in the world. The museum complex covers an entire city block and includes 20 exhibit galleries, featuring five complete whale skeletons as well as artwork by major American artists who lived or worked in the New Bedford area. Collections of art and furniture from the 19th century serve as a reminder of the immense wealth generated by the whaling industry.
The whaling museum attracts visitors year-round, but it becomes a holy site during the Moby-Dick Marathon, held traditionally on the first weekend in January. Events are staged over three days and include a dinner and lecture with Melville experts, a “Stump the Scholars” session and discussions about art, whaling and New Bedford. Hot coffee flows through the night, and gift bags are distributed to those who make it through all 25 hours of the marathon.
“We had our largest crowd in history this year with 3,193 people,” says Annelise Conway, the museum’s chief engagement officer. “Some are Melville die-hards. Some are literary tourists who come for the bucket-list experience.”
If the whaling museum is the high altar, then the Seamen’s Bethel is the chapel. The marathon moves briefly to this location just across the street for the chapters on a portentous sermon about the biblical prophet Jonah, who was swallowed by a whale. Visitors cram into this simple chantry, where the walls are lined with cenotaphs dedicated to New Bedford sailors who lost their lives on faraway seas.
Melville and his brother Gansevoort visited the bethel, built in 1832 as a spiritual haven for mariners, just prior to departing New Bedford to “go a-whaling” on the ship Acushnet. Little has changed at the old mission, except for the pulpit, which the New Bedford Port Society restyled in 1961 to resemble the prow of a ship depicted in the 1956 movie Moby Dick, starring Gregory Peck and Richard Basehart.
Within the next 15 months, the city will install a statue honoring Herman Melville on the grounds of the Seamen’s Bethel. Standing over seven feet tall, the bronze sculpture with a grey patina will feature the author in a sea swell framed by three large whale ribs.
A treasured tradition
For Don Kreis of Concord, New Hampshire, the Moby-Dick Marathon has become an annual pilgrimage of sorts. He read at last year’s event and decided to do so again this year with his 24-year-old daughter, Rose Keller, who lives in Augusta, Maine. Both are “Moby-Dick fanatics, like people who go to Grateful Dead concerts,” he says. He read the novel to her when she was a baby, and both call it their favorite book.
For the 2026 marathon, they selected the 3 a.m. time slot, with father going first, followed by his daughter. Despite the hour, the museum gallery where the marathon concludes was packed with reverential souls, all listening intently.
When Kreis stepped to the podium, he began reading “Chapter 81, The Pequod Meets the Virgin.” This is when the New Bedford ship encounters a Dutch vessel that has not yet harvested a whale, known as a “virgin” to the salty whalemen. The two ships then launch their smaller boats of harpooneers to chase the same sperm whale.
“When you sign up to read, you don’t get to pick the section—just the time,” Kreis says. “As I started reading, I realized it was Rose’s favorite chapter. I started reading it and then she took over after five minutes. We call this our ‘Moby-Dick Miracle.’”
Both father and daughter are planning to read at the 2027 Moby-Dick Marathon.
Perhaps it’s preaching to the choir, but the entire weekend is devoted to celebrating the one true religion as passed down by a prophet and literary genius who understood the spiritual needs of successive generations of readers.
“We know that Moby-Dick is relevant,” Conway says. “We know people still want to read that book and understand it and really dissect it.”
